column5: MY EYES!!!  One can not unsee what has been seen. :closedeyes:
That was my next guess.  JF
Nice! looks like you get her all fixed up! How long did it take???? Cost?
Yer still talking about the boat - right?  JF
I think he's talking about the paddles in the boat?  Did you use a "hard wood"?
Ha ha ! Good stuff guys! I know Im a little late here but I was busy working on my project. That is all.
I guess you could sit in it and make noises Bruce !!!!  No.. it's the real deal.. hope to be re-installing the motor by the end of next week.  The bent up pics are on page 1..
Done.  http://www.ofncommunity.com/forums/index.p...c=41414&hl=
Holy crap...it's GCD!! Where have you been you backwards redneck?

Looks like. A few years ago I picked up an RZ500 that had blown a head gasket and the owner had let sit with the cylinder full of coolant.  I no longer have a wistful yearning for a street going two-smoker, heh. I had done some tweaking to my 600 Ninja, got everything buttoned up, and somebody has sideswiped it in the parking garage.  Again.

That would get nasty in a hurry!  In my early days of aquariums, I made this mistake.  I put a very nasty little Pseudotropheus in with a couple of convicts.  It was my first African. Oh boy....I can see the convicts now.  There wasnt a fin left on any of them! Poor buggers!  It was like bringing a starving Mike Tyson to a soup kitchen full of wanna be tough guys.  Ab

Yup, there are few DT 250's, and few RT 360's (1970-1973), and even one CT, napping around the house/garage.  I'm in the middle of waking them up right now from a long hibernation.  I have had my R6's, my YZF's ... bikes that would stretch the skin at @ 250 kph, but you know what?  These guys are more fun!  Sorry to hear about accident on the Ninja.  It's good that you okay and able to write about it.
I sure miss my '68 DT1b. It was my first bike. I'd like to find another just for an about town scooter.  JF
The 68 was a very special bike indeed!  If you find one in Ontario, there will be a race to it!
After I said that I got to wondering if it was '68 or '69. It was a golf tank with white pinstriping. I think they changed the tank colour the next year.  JF
I looked 'em up and it must have been the '68. I remember there were white tanks and gold tanks. The following year they went to a nasty orange tank.  JF

That is correct.  The 68 was white, the 69 was goldy orange, and the 70 was red.  If you end up finding that 68 bike under your deck, or packed away somewhere in your garage, give me a call!  I hear they are really dangerous to ride, and the wheels fall off from time to time, and on occasion it turns left when you want to go right, and I also hear that the seat pops up and ejects the rider over small little bumps in the road.  So you really don't want a bike like that, now do you?

Yup.  A bunch of the guys I rode with back then had Bonnevilles, one Sportster, Beezers (forget what the twin carb 650 was called), a Commando. We used to go out to a local farm that had a nice hill out back and pretend we were big time hillclimbers. The other guys could never figger out how my little 250 beat their 650/750's every time. We even changed riders and the Yammie was always fast. The twins threw up a nice rooster tail though.  I had changed the primary sprocket and ran an MX tire but the engine was basically stock.  JF

That sounds like a lot of fun John.  Would be interesting to stretch the DT frame for the climbs and see how that performs!  I would love to have an old British twin.  Put an old CT up against the heavy twins and I bet it would be the same result.  You should find yourself a scoot.  Life is too short to tell yourself to hold on and wait for the opportunity (to an extent).  It's definitely affordable, and certainly has been a great memorable experience in your life.  It will make you happy, and that's something you can't put a price tag on.  You can apply this to all of the interesting hobbies mentioned in this thread.  If you know it will make you happy, and it's attainable to you, then go for it and get it done!  Everything we do here keeps us together, for ourselves and for others.  It's an important part of life, whatever it is that we do.  What is it that we do?  Oh yeah, fishing.  See?

I have a spring project now. I have to get my house ready to sell. Finishing all my little projects that were good enough at the time and I will fix that up laters. A bit of electrical wiring, a bit of trim here and there, paint touch ups, hiding tv and internet cables.  Good part is I get to build myself a new and improved shop..oh yeah, the wife is building the house she wants too.
Nice fish!

My last bike was a big black Ninja. That was about 20 years ago. As much as I like the crotch rockets I might look a little odd riding 'em at my age.  Besides, I'd probably lose my licence. Cops get hinky about riding the back wheel in town.  I figger a nice little 250 enduro wouldn't be bad for ripping around town.  JF
Here's what I've been working on. I must admit, every minute has been a pleasure....
The boat?  JF
nope, whats in it, lol
First one out of the it's mold. Another bunch (50   ) to run that won't break the bank...  Painting them is half the fun.
I need something in the photo for scale gbfisher. I'd like to see those through the stages as well.
They are 9" take off is all. There's only 3 stages left, hardware, paint and clear coat.
No John.. I think the dog...
scary stuff........
Yah got that right.. and a disclaimer!! I took the picture from his gallery... I did not take it myself!!
Just for fun throw in an African.  JF
Working on my wood carving's. So far, an Elephant, Seahorse, Loon, and a Red Cardinal. None  finished yet but will be for the first Carving show in March.
i don't have any pics but i'm working on building a float rod.
New cabinet for my tackle making suplies and inventory. Old cabinet was collapsing from the weight of lead.  Hundreds of harnesses to make  and the never ending project

Well for me this winter to continue not smoking to learn how to play the axe better and to rebuild the Marshall JCM 900.(want my balls to vibrate) Plus various honey doo"s that I will post through out the winter not big on hard water fishing so got some time to play and to do a step by step(Pics) water pump change out for all the good folks on OFC  and waiting for my KILT  Peter

Here's a couple of muskie lures I just finished...Last picture has a bagley bang O to compare sizes.... Next job is to make a tray for the pedal of my trolling motor, going to make it from stainless steel.

Sure is a lot of talented folks here.  Well in my post surgery boredom I decided to break out the fly tying gear after what is likely a 20 year hiatus. I haven't tied to many and I'm definitely a little rusty! Fingers are not as nimble as they once were and my failing eyesight is clearly apparent, to me at least. I've also been playing with new techniques and materials, like bead head jigs.   Here's a few from the past couple of weeks.          This one just came together about half an hour ago....
Those are beautiful, Chris.  Makes me want to reach for a can of RAID!

i'll be building a small wall unit for the basement tv.  also continuing making some steelhead floats.  i'll post some pics later. was planning on starting today but its bloody cold, even in the garage
Nice legs.
Thank you, thank you.  With the basic skills slowly returning I hope to improve with practice.
Sooooo  Chris can you make me a Pike sized minnow fly between now and Lak Air? I will trade you a real manly muskie lure for it.     Art
And you DO make quality musky baits Art, that's fer sure !!

Well I've never made anything bigger than trout flies Art but I'd be happy to try for you considering all you've done for me. The fundamentals would be the same just have to up scale them a bit, okay a lot. How would you plan on fishing them?   While I'm here this one just came out of the vise about 20 minutes ago. Been playing with some new material for the legs.
AWESOME design and details on that fly Chris.... I like it
WOW!  Betcha Solopaddler and a few others would take a few of those if you had the time to make them. Excellent work, Bud.
So how hard do i have to beg to get this little jewel made.  Thanks  Art
Oh that shouldn't be too difficult....
Incredible job on those flies Spiel, very easy to see why the fish grab those things
Havent you learned I am a pain in the butt????   Art
Disco, are those DT- era Yammies? Takes me back!

thanks Jacques, perhaps I should try a BumbleBee pattern next.   Hopefully he won't see them Roy.   Thanks Lew. Be it musky or trout matching the hatch as it were is the name of the game.   I'm starting to catch on.
agreed
So Art... how are you and Joe making out on that 83 Virago ???  I'm still plugging away at my project... may even get to go fishing on time if I keep at it!
Am I seeing things, or are you rebuilding a ground trainer/simulator.

I know of a few people here that carve, whittle,make lures or paint. Lets see some of the winters projects and how they are coming along. Joe and I are working at bringing a 83 Virago back to new life but are still working on the mechanical stuff so it is not very photogenic yet.   Art

About the only winter project I have time for is an extensive photo essay of a canoe trip I took to the Arctic Ocean almost 12 years ago. Long before I had a digital camera. I hope to post it some time in February when things are getting a little slow and the spring opener still seams to be soooo long away.
nothing exciting here.......christmas took up too much of my time so far, and fishing lol going to be gutting and drywalling the kitchen soon Yippeeeee
This went from an idea to a major project fairly quickly. Should be lots of fun. BWPF_OOD_Ad.pdf

No pics but my wife says so, so it must be.....  Presently I have three 75 gallon and one 90 gallon aquariums stacked two high in my rec room.  My wife says I must "downsize" to two tanks (she wants the one wall for an entertainment centre).  I told her I can do, but the two tanks will be a bit longer and a bit wider.  She says "OK"....  So........ I am setting up two 180 gallon tanks, stacked two high!!!!  Picking up the custom metal stand on Friday....  Burt
Nice setup Burtess... what'cha keep?
Mostly Central and SA cichlids.  One big Rose Queen (flowerhorn) as well....  Burt
I have a couple of projects on the go. The first is website development for a lodge and the second is to fish as many of these lakes before ice out as humanly possible.
Here's one that I worked on during the Christmas holidays..... it's a gift for my brother in law that was given to him on New Years day....    Leechman
Gonna make this look like new by spring... (or I won't be allowed to go back to the camp for the summer)

Just picked up some balsa wood to make another attempt at steelhead floats, I poured 500 jigheads on ultrapoint hooks and 200 on owner deepcut flip n pitch hooks, have 20 muskybaits carved out of clear pine and cedar, 7 deepdivers and 13 jerkbaits that are waiting to be airbrushed and epoxied, as well Im fishing steelhead when ever the conditions are favorable, winters go by quick when you have a hobby or two
I'm working on jigs, i'll make a post when they are complete!

My landlord has a bunch of Dehaviland Beavers that look like that!! Worse actually. They're his retirement projects. He's currently working on one of them but I think he has 5 or 6 that are pretty bent up.    Thanks for reminding me. I also picked up about $35 worth of 1x1x36 inch balsa to build some more floats. Plus I have several rods waiting to be built, snowmobile trailer that needs work (when it warms up some), the list goes on and on.

I have to get these ready for the spring so that I can race everyone at the cottage and dodge trees and little critters.  I know, cramped work area in my basement!          I am working on this all in 2009 till present.  It is an endless project and always on the go, especially during off season.  This winter I want to install a wide rear tire (tranny and swing arm mods)  before:    during:    now:    But who has the time when we are all out fishing???!!!  Hahaha!  Disco
Here's my winter project!    You wimps!!!
Nothin' that couldn't be done in 2-3 lifetimes.

Here was my little restoration project for this winter. It was 50 years old. I was given this for Christmas 1959. Here's a link to a thread where I obtained the missing info for the Briscoe's decal. http://www.urbantoronto.ca/showthread.php?t=10545 It was painted a 1959 Massey Harris red.
This one started Winter 09 and is continuing Winter 10 should rap up Winter 11 just in time to move it up to Bancroft with me sometime around Winter 2012! It's a 1960 Dodge Sweptline.
Dressing up like gumby is not a winter project glen..

... and you would think that if you'd caught anything of any worth recently you'd have taken a pic with that nice new camera you got for Christmas... or are you still skeered squatless that you'll hold the fish wrong and someone will bring it to your attention???  For a nominal fee... I can teach you how to take a self timer pic of you and your fish!... for an additional fee I can explain to you which fish is in season and which one isn't!

my next winter project was supposed learn how to make a chair....but now thats been put on hold so i can make a rocking horse for my granddaughter....yeah me !!!! If my wife sees this thread she is going to want me to put her car back together...
To go from this    to this    and to look down one of these once in a while
Dan your not going to win any marathons with little legs like that   ...ya might need to laminate them to hold up that upper body
Is he eating CAKE???
